newsitem.title: FRANCE: Workers free Giat bosses held in job cuts protest.
newsitem.headline: Workers free Giat bosses held in job cuts protest.

text.p: Eleven executives of state arms-maker Giat Industries were freed on Tuesday after being taken hostage the previous day at a plant in southwest France by workers protesting job cuts.
"The hostage-taking (at the Tarbes plant) is over," a spokeswoman for Giat said. She added the incident ended peacefully and that the police had not been called to intervene.
The executives were locked in their offices on Monday by 200 workers who invaded the premises.
Production was halted at the plant, which produces turrets for the Leclerc tanks, the spokeswoman said.
The workers occupied the plant premises overnight but a union spokesman said they left after freeing the executives.
The Giat spokeswoman said the company was appealing to workers "to return to work as normal" on Wednesday.

The executives were released after union members voted massively in favour of freeing them, said Jean-Louis Naudet, secretary-general of the Federation des Travailleurs, affiliated with the communist-led CGT.
But Naudet told Reuters the workers "would keep up the fight" against Giat's plans to axe 595 jobs out of a total of 1,800 at the Tarbes site.
The company is planning to cut 2,569 out of 12,000 employees to focus on its core business of tanks, armoured vehicles and munitions.
"We want a withdrawal of the plan," Naudet said.
It was the second time in less than a month that workers at the plant had taken such action. On October 3, they took the plant director hostage and occupied the plant.
The Giat job cuts are part of a larger reform of the French defence industry, which has been hit by a drop in orders since the end of the Cold War and reduced defence budgets.
Giat reported a net loss of 10 billion francs for 1995.
